herbivoor.Description.DwarfScrollI: A yellowed scroll of parchment filled with dwarven script. This one's tied with a red ribbon.
herbivoor.Description.DwarfScrollII: A yellowed scroll of parchment filled with dwarven script. This one's tied with a green ribbon.
herbivoor.Description.DwarfScrollIII: A yellowed scroll of parchment filled with dwarven script. This one's tied with a blue ribbon.
herbivoor.Description.DwarfScrollIV: A yellowed scroll of parchment filled with dwarven script. This one's tied with a golden ribbon.
herbivoor.Description.PrehistoricScapula: Commonly known as "shoulder blades"... It's unclear what species it belonged to.
herbivoor.Description.PrehistoricTibiae: Two thick and sturdy leg bones.
herbivoor.Description.SkeletalHands: It's a wonder all these ancient little pieces lasted so long.
herbivoor.Description.PrehistoricRibcage: Little gouge marks on the side suggest that this ribcage was someone's dinner.
herbivoor.Description.PrehistoricVertebr: A long segment of some prehistoric creature's spine.
herbivoor.Description.SkeletalTail: The tail of some prehistoric creature.
herbivoor.Description.ElvishJewelry: Incredibly old, but still beautiful. On the side is a flowing script thought by some to be the ancient language of the elves. No Elvish bones have ever been found.
herbivoor.Description.AncientDoll: A small, ancient doll covered in grime. This doll may have been used as a toy, a decoration, or a prop in some kind of ritual. It has an insidious red glow and its body is almost devoid of color. Just looking at it makes you feel uneasy.
herbivoor.Description.StrangeDoll1: A large, rounded doll made from some kind of porcelain. It appears to have previously been broken apart and painstakingly pieced back together again. It looks very old and the color has faded significantly.
herbivoor.Description.StrangeDoll2: A medium sized porcelain doll. Its head appears to have been smashed clean off and the color looks as if it has been drained.
herbivoor.Description.PrehistoricTools: Some kind of gnarly old digging tools.
